papers.title: 'Breathing' Hemagglutinin Reveals Cryptic Epitopes for Universal Influenza Vaccine Design
papers.findings: This is a preview for 3 independent studies on HA breathing in this issue. These studies revealed occluded epitopes on the HA head that are exposed when the HA is breathing, where the inter-protomer HA head domain contact surface can be recognized by Abs. Surprisingly, Abs targeting these area lacked neutralizing activity in vitro, but they do have protective efficacy in mouse model of infection. Notably, these Abs can recognize a large range of flu HA subtypes.

papers.title: Antigenic structure of the haemagglutinin of human influenza A/H2N2 virus
papers.findings: H2N2 circulated for 11 years in human. In stark contrast to H3N2 and H1N1, it never added N-linked glycosylation to its head domain. In vitro, however, glycosylation was added to escape from mAbs recognition but it comes with a great fitness cost, namely reduction in receptor-binding and membrane-fusion activity.

papers.title: Human Influenza A Virus Hemagglutinin Glycan Evolution Follows a Temporal Pattern to a Glycan Limit
papers.findings: Glycan addition shifts kDa substantially but varies by subtype; H1 adds ~3.3 kDa/glycan, H3 adds ~2.5 kDa/glycan. IAVs add glycans at an interval of 5-7 years, to which afterwards they start swapping.

papers.title: Influenza virus transcription and progeny production are poorly correlated in single cells
Segment-Specific Kinetics of mRNA, cRNA, and vRNA Accumulation during Influenza Virus Infection
Fitness costs limit influenza A virus hemagglutinin glycosylation as an immune evasion strategy
papers.findings: Here the authors discussed H28-A2 mAb (IgM), where notably it generated PR8 escape at an extremely low frequency of 1 in 1 billion (10<sup>â€“9.12</sup>), a frequency that corresponds to a simultaneous double mutant despite having a typical anti-HA affinity. The footprint of H28-A2 is unknown. A single K144N substitution is enough to escape H28-A2, but PR8 typically evolved with a compensatory mutation elsewhere on the HA (either P186S, D225G or N193K; all these substitutions confer high avidity binding to sialic acid). Surprisingly, H28-A2 escape mutants can't escape polyclonal Ab well. This suggests that H28-A2 escape mutants (with the aforementioned compensatory mutations) prioritized for receptor avidity than Ab escape.
